block.p: ''A Break in the Acid Rain Impasse'' (editorial, June 7), which challenges potential critics to support the cleanup proposal by New York's Gov. Mario Cuomo and Ohio's Gov. Richard Celeste or to come up with a better one, obscures the issue.

Support for specifics in this plan, which divides the costs between an oil-import tax and ratepayers, would be premature. Proposed emissions reductions are too modest; 15 years to attain them is too long. The groundbreaking funding mechanisms that the plan proposes need better incentives. Yet what matters is not the specifics, but the proposal's three-part breakthrough in the acid-rain debate.

* It has reintroduced the concept of civic fellowship. Acid rain is a major assault on the sense of American community, a claim that one region may blight another simply because it is profitable to do so.
* It solves the polluters-should-pay problem. The levy on oil imports also avoids the trap of overburdening Eastern utility rates already high with pollution-control expenses.

* What makes the levy on oil imports more than a clever trick is that it flows from the context of energy policy. Thus, acid rain controls become an aspect of wise infrastructure management, capable of providing net billions of dollars in economic and social benefits.
In Congress, the acid rain debate remains stalemated, with little immediate hope for more than pseudocompromise.

Genuine breakthrough awaits a public consensus on basic principles. The Cuomo-Celeste initiative is not unique in many specifics. What it offers is an approach that, if taken, can lead to a national consensus on principles that will finally produce action on acid rain control.

For this, both of the governors deserve great praise. It is to be hoped that their partnership will continue and that, working through institutions like the New England and Midwestern governors conferences, and the Cuomo Economic Commission, their proposal will promote a constructive interregional dialogue to bring the acid rain debate to a successfull conclusion. ALBERT F. APPLETON V.P. and Conservation Chmn. New York City Audubon Society New York, June 22, 1988
